trans-unit.source: PowerShell Desired State Configuration partial configurations
trans-unit.target: PowerShell Desired State Configuration partial configurations

trans-unit.source: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 5.0
trans-unit.target: Applies To: Windows PowerShell 5.0

trans-unit.source: In PowerShell 5.0, Desired State Configuration (DSC) allows configurations to be delivered in fragments and from multiple sources.
trans-unit.target: In PowerShell 5.0, Desired State Configuration (DSC) allows configurations to be delivered in fragments and from multiple sources.

trans-unit.source: The Local Configuration Manager (LCM) on the target node puts the fragments together before applying them as a single configuration.
trans-unit.target: The Local Configuration Manager (LCM) on the target node puts the fragments together before applying them as a single configuration.

trans-unit.source: This capability allows sharing control of configuration between teams or individuals.
trans-unit.target: This capability allows sharing control of configuration between teams or individuals.

trans-unit.source: For example, if two or more teams of developers are collaborating on a service, they might each want to create configurations to manage their part of the service.
trans-unit.target: For example, if two or more teams of developers are collaborating on a service, they might each want to create configurations to manage their part of the service.

trans-unit.source: Each of these configurations could be pulled from different pull servers, and they could be added at different stages of development.
trans-unit.target: Each of these configurations could be pulled from different pull servers, and they could be added at different stages of development.

trans-unit.source: Partial configurations also allow different individuals or teams to control different aspects of configuring nodes without having to coordinate the editing of a single configuration document.
trans-unit.target: Partial configurations also allow different individuals or teams to control different aspects of configuring nodes without having to coordinate the editing of a single configuration document.

trans-unit.source: For example, one team might be responsible for deploying a VM and operating system, while another team might deploy other applications and services on that VM.
trans-unit.target: For example, one team might be responsible for deploying a VM and operating system, while another team might deploy other applications and services on that VM.

trans-unit.source: With partial configurations, each team can create its own configuration, without either of them being unnecessarily complicated.
trans-unit.target: With partial configurations, each team can create its own configuration, without either of them being unnecessarily complicated.

trans-unit.source: You can use partial configurations in push mode, pull mode, or a combination of the two.
trans-unit.target: You can use partial configurations in push mode, pull mode, or a combination of the two.

trans-unit.source: Partial configurations in push mode
trans-unit.target: Partial configurations in push mode

trans-unit.source: To use partial configurations in push mode, you configure the LCM on the target node to receive the partial configurations.
trans-unit.target: To use partial configurations in push mode, you configure the LCM on the target node to receive the partial configurations.

trans-unit.source: Each partial configuration must be pushed to the target by using the Publish-DSCConfiguration cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Each partial configuration must be pushed to the target by using the Publish-DSCConfiguration cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: The target node then combines the partial configuration into a single configuration, and you can apply the configuration by calling the [Start-DscConfigurationxt](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn521623.aspx) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The target node then combines the partial configuration into a single configuration, and you can apply the configuration by calling the [Start-DscConfigurationxt](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn521623.aspx) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Configuring the LCM for push-mode partial configurations
trans-unit.target: Configuring the LCM for push-mode partial configurations

trans-unit.source: To configure the LCM for partial configurations in push mode, you create a **DSCLocalConfigurationManager** configuration with one **PartialConfiguration** block for each partial configuration.
trans-unit.target: To configure the LCM for partial configurations in push mode, you create a **DSCLocalConfigurationManager** configuration with one **PartialConfiguration** block for each partial configuration.

trans-unit.source: For more information about configuring the LCM, see [Windows Configuring the Local Configuration Manager](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt421188.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information about configuring the LCM, see [Windows Configuring the Local Configuration Manager](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/mt421188.aspx).

trans-unit.target: The following example shows an LCM configuration that expects two partial configurations—one that deploys the OS, and one that deploys and configures SharePoint.

trans-unit.source: The **RefreshMode** for each partial configuration is set to "Push".
trans-unit.target: The **RefreshMode** for each partial configuration is set to "Push".

trans-unit.source: The names of the **PartialConfiguration** blocks (in this case, "OSInstall" and "SharePointConfig") must match exactly the names of the configurations that are pushed to the target node.
trans-unit.target: The names of the **PartialConfiguration** blocks (in this case, "OSInstall" and "SharePointConfig") must match exactly the names of the configurations that are pushed to the target node.

trans-unit.source: Partial configurations in pull mode
trans-unit.target: Partial configurations in pull mode

trans-unit.source: Partial configurations can be pulled from one or more pull servers (for more information about pull servers, see [Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration Pull Servers](pullServer.md).
trans-unit.target: Partial configurations can be pulled from one or more pull servers (for more information about pull servers, see [Windows PowerShell Desired State Configuration Pull Servers](pullServer.md).

trans-unit.source: To do this, you have to configure the LCM on the target node to pull the partial configurations, and name and locate the configuration documents properly on the pull servers.
trans-unit.target: To do this, you have to configure the LCM on the target node to pull the partial configurations, and name and locate the configuration documents properly on the pull servers.

trans-unit.source: Configuring the LCM for pull node configurations
trans-unit.target: Configuring the LCM for pull node configurations

trans-unit.source: To configure the LCM to pull partial configurations from a pull server, you define the pull server in either a **ConfigurationRepositoryWeb** (for an HTTP pull server) or **ConfigurationRepositoryShare** (for an SMB pull server) block.
trans-unit.target: To configure the LCM to pull partial configurations from a pull server, you define the pull server in either a **ConfigurationRepositoryWeb** (for an HTTP pull server) or **ConfigurationRepositoryShare** (for an SMB pull server) block.

trans-unit.source: You then create **PartialConfiguration** blocks that refer to the pull server by using the **ConfigurationSource** property.
trans-unit.target: You then create **PartialConfiguration** blocks that refer to the pull server by using the **ConfigurationSource** property.

trans-unit.source: You also need to create a Settings block to specify that the LCM uses pull mode, and to specify the ConfigurationID that the pull server and target node use to identify the configurations.
trans-unit.target: You also need to create a Settings block to specify that the LCM uses pull mode, and to specify the ConfigurationID that the pull server and target node use to identify the configurations.

trans-unit.source: You can pull partial configurations from more than one pull server—you would just need to define each pull server, and then refer to the appropriate pull server in each PartialConfiguration block.
trans-unit.target: You can pull partial configurations from more than one pull server—you would just need to define each pull server, and then refer to the appropriate pull server in each PartialConfiguration block.

trans-unit.source: After creating the meta-configuration, you must run it to create a configuration document (a MOF file), and then call [Set-DscLocalConfigurationManager](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn521621(v=wps.630).aspx) to configure the LCM.
trans-unit.target: After creating the meta-configuration, you must run it to create a configuration document (a MOF file), and then call [Set-DscLocalConfigurationManager](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dn521621(v=wps.630).aspx) to configure the LCM.

trans-unit.source: Naming and placing the configuration documents on the pull server
trans-unit.target: Naming and placing the configuration documents on the pull server

trans-unit.source: The partial configuration documents must be placed in the folder specified as the **ConfigurationPath** in the `web.config` file for the pull server (typically `C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\DscService\Configuration`).
trans-unit.target: The partial configuration documents must be placed in the folder specified as the **ConfigurationPath** in the `web.config` file for the pull server (typically `C:\Program Files\WindowsPowerShell\DscService\Configuration`).

trans-unit.source: The configuration documents must be named as follows: _ConfigurationName_.
trans-unit.target: The configuration documents must be named as follows: _ConfigurationName_.

trans-unit.source: Running partial configurations from a pull server

trans-unit.source: After the LCM on the target node has been configured, and the configuration documents have been created and properly named on the pull server, the target node will pull the partial configurations, combine them, and apply the resulting configuration at regular intervals as specified by the **RefreshFrequencyMins** property of the LCM.
trans-unit.target: After the LCM on the target node has been configured, and the configuration documents have been created and properly named on the pull server, the target node will pull the partial configurations, combine them, and apply the resulting configuration at regular intervals as specified by the **RefreshFrequencyMins** property of the LCM.

trans-unit.source: If you want to force a refresh, you can call the Update-DscConfiguration cmdlet, to pull the configurations, and then `Start-DSCConfiguration –UseExisting` to apply them.
trans-unit.target: If you want to force a refresh, you can call the Update-DscConfiguration cmdlet, to pull the configurations, and then `Start-DSCConfiguration –UseExisting` to apply them.

trans-unit.source: Partial configurations in mixed push and pull modes
trans-unit.target: Partial configurations in mixed push and pull modes

trans-unit.source: You can also mix push and pull modes for partial configurations.
trans-unit.target: You can also mix push and pull modes for partial configurations.

trans-unit.source: That is, you could have one partial configuration that is pulled from a pull server, while another partial configuration is pushed.
trans-unit.target: That is, you could have one partial configuration that is pulled from a pull server, while another partial configuration is pushed.

trans-unit.source: Treat each partial configuration as you would, depending on its refresh mode as described in the previous sections.
trans-unit.target: Treat each partial configuration as you would, depending on its refresh mode as described in the previous sections.
